articles.headline: Unhappy With a Moderate Jeb Bush, Conservatives Aim to Unite Behind an Alternative
articles.snippet: Leaders of evangelical and socially conservative groups who believe that only a conservative can rally the base to win in 2016 have been vetting some contenders.
articles.abstract: Leaders of evangelical and socially conservative groups who believe that only a conservative can rally the base to win in 2016 have been vetting some contenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSKALOOSA, Iowa — Fearing that Republicans will ultimately nominate an establishment presidential candidate like Jeb Bush, leaders of the nation’s Christian right have mounted an ambitious effort to coalesce their support behind a single social-conservative contender months before the first primary votes are cast.

articles.headline: Bowe Bergdahl Charged With Desertion and Misbehavior Before the Enemy
articles.snippet: The charges for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was held captive in Afghanistan, raised the possibility that he could be imprisoned again, this time for life.
articles.abstract: The charges for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, who was held captive in Afghanistan, raised the possibility that he could be imprisoned again, this time for life.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the five years he was held captive by the Haqqani insurgent network, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl recalls that he tried to escape 12 times. The first time was just a few hours after he was captured in Afghanistan in 2009.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Parrying the Latest Predictions of Facebook’s Demise
articles.snippet: A theory making the rounds in Silicon Valley warns that Facebook relies too heavily on app ads from start-ups inflated by venture capital. But the threat is overblown.
articles.abstract: A theory making the rounds in Silicon Valley warns that Facebook relies too heavily on app ads from start-ups inflated by venture capital. But the threat is overblown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every few years, a strange affliction breaks out in Silicon Valley. The disease, Facebook Second Guessing Syndrome, has as its worst symptom an embarrassing tendency to predict an early peak for the fortunes of the world’s largest social network.

articles.headline: Veterans Hurt by Chemical Weapons in Iraq Get Apology
articles.snippet: The Army under secretary, Brad R. Carson, said that those suffering from exposure to the weapons would be accounted for and offered medical screening.
articles.abstract: The Army under secretary, Brad R. Carson, said that those suffering from exposure to the weapons would be accounted for and offered medical screening.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The under secretary of the Army on Wednesday apologized for the military’s treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq, and he announced new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects and to recognize veterans who had been denied awards.

articles.headline: Apple and Beats Developing Streaming Music Service to Rival Spotify
articles.snippet: The new system will not have a lower price than its competitors, and won’t offer a free version supported by ads.
articles.abstract: The new system will not have a lower price than its competitors, and won’t offer a free version supported by ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: In what would be the biggest change to its music strategy in years, Apple is pressing ahead with a sweeping overhaul of its digital music services that would allow the company to compete directly with streaming upstarts like Spotify.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Trans-Pacific Partnership Seen as Door for Foreign Suits Against U.S.
articles.snippet: The 12-nation accord would let foreign corporations challenge American actions and regulations that hurt their business, a classified document obtained by The Times says.
articles.abstract: The 12-nation accord would let foreign corporations challenge American actions and regulations that hurt their business, a classified document obtained by The Times says.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An ambitious 12-nation trade accord pushed by President Obama would allow foreign corporations to sue the United States government for actions that undermine their investment “expectations” and hurt their business, according to a classified document.

articles.headline: Drones Beaming Web Access Are in the Stars for Facebook
articles.snippet: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle is the centerpiece of the social network’s plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach.
articles.abstract: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle is the centerpiece of the social network’s plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In classical mythology, Aquila is the eagle carrying Jupiter’s thunderbolts skyward. At Facebook, it is the code name for a high-flying drone, indicative of the social networking company’s lofty ambitions.
articles.byline: By Quentin Hardy and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Fatal Descent of Germanwings Plane Was ‘Deliberate,’ French Authorities Say
articles.snippet: The co-pilot initiated the plane’s descent for unknown reasons while he was alone in the cockpit, having locked the pilot out, said the prosecutor.
articles.abstract: The co-pilot initiated the plane’s descent for unknown reasons while he was alone in the cockpit, having locked the pilot out, said the prosecutor.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Andreas Lubitz was breathing, steady and calm, in the final moments of Germanwings Flight 9525. It was the only sound from within the cockpit that the voice recorder detected as Mr. Lubitz, the co-pilot, sent the plane into its descent.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: As Dollar Heats Up Overseas, U.S. Manufacturers Feel a Chill
articles.snippet: Customers in places like Europe, where the euro has fallen against the dollar, say they can no longer afford American goods without deep discounts.
articles.abstract: Customers in places like Europe, where the euro has fallen against the dollar, say they can no longer afford American goods without deep discounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dollar’s sharp rise in recent months has left Robert Stevenson and Eastman Machine, his family’s 127-year-old Buffalo company, feeling the heat on both sides of the Atlantic.

articles.headline: Richard III Gets a Kingly Burial, on Second Try
articles.snippet: The archbishop of Canterbury presided over the service on Thursday, but critics said the notorious monarch should not have been given such honors.
articles.abstract: The archbishop of Canterbury presided over the service on Thursday, but critics said the notorious monarch should not have been given such honors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — For an English monarchy that has lasted more than 1,000 years, there can have been few more improbable occasions than the ceremony of remembrance here on Thursday for the reburial of one of the most bloodstained medieval sovereigns, King Richard III, who was slain in battle seven years before Christopher Columbus set sail for the New World.

articles.headline: As Twitter Introduces Periscope, Tech Titans Bet on Live Streaming Video
articles.snippet: Apps that help users broadcast themselves live from their phones are catching the eye of tech heavyweights and venture capitalists. Periscope is Twitter’s big entry into this realm.
articles.abstract: Apps that help users broadcast themselves live from their phones are catching the eye of tech heavyweights and venture capitalists. Periscope is Twitter’s big entry into this realm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tyra Banks smiled a toothy grin and chatted idly with a captive audience this week, showing off her new pixie haircut. She later flipped a blond-streaked auburn lock at the crowd, asking in a half-mocking tone, “How do you like me now?”
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Bargain Hunting With a Strong Dollar in Europe, but Finding a Mixed Bag
articles.snippet: With the euro approaching parity with the dollar, it seems to be time for a shopping spree on the Continent. But currency fluctuations are complicated.
articles.abstract: With the euro approaching parity with the dollar, it seems to be time for a shopping spree on the Continent. But currency fluctuations are complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the euro approaching parity with the United States dollar for the first time in over a decade, it’s time to dust off your passport, grab your wallet and embark on a shopping spree in Europe.

articles.headline: Andreas Lubitz, Who Loved to Fly, Ended Up on a Mysterious and Deadly Course
articles.snippet: The co-pilot accused of deliberately crashing a plane into the Alps passed all medical and flying tests, Lufthansa officials said.
articles.abstract: The co-pilot accused of deliberately crashing a plane into the Alps passed all medical and flying tests, Lufthansa officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was 27, loved to fly and apparently raised no suspicions or showed obvious signs that he was troubled.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Payday Loan Rules Proposed by Consumer Protection Agency
articles.snippet: The rules proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would require lenders to assess customers’ ability to repay short-term loans.
articles.abstract: The rules proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would require lenders to assess customers’ ability to repay short-term loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the agency created at President Obama’s urging in the aftermath of the financial crisis, took its most aggressive step yet on behalf of consumers on Thursday, proposing regulations to rein in short-term payday loans that often have interest rates of 400 percent or more.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
